results.title: After trousers [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Oxford Film and Television, BBC, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Richard Curson Smith
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, thirty-five years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode four examines the 200 year history of cross cultural appropriation since Aborigines first made contact with white settlers, a period referred to as “after trousers”. Particular attention is paid to the plight of Aboriginals in Tasmania, from King Billy and Truganini to the claim by current residents of their Aboriginal ancestry. Hughes travels to the home of the Bush mob, the last known group to have made contact with whites in 1984 before being reunited with the rest of their Pintubi community. He also visits Hermansburg Mission and speaks of the influence of Christianity, instilled by Lutheran missionaries over the years as well as touching on the forced removal of aboriginal children. He talks to opera singer Deborah Cheetham, one of the stolen generation, about her relationship with her biological mother and her thoughts on the matter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oxford Film and Television, BBC, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Richard Curson Smith

results.title: After the whale
results.creator_credit: Time-Life Films and L. Richard Ellison
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Around Us”.
Probably the most misunderstood animal, the whale is shown in this film to be a playful, shy, browsing mammal, defenceless against us and on the verge of extinction.

results.title: After the Warming
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Richard Sattin and Mike Slee
results.brief_description: It is the year 2050. Mankind and the earth have survived global warming. In an innovative new television project, social journalist James Burke looks back from the future of several scenarios of global warming and their possible effects on continents, countries and mankind. He explores the preventative roads not taken and the potential results.

results.title: After the Tsunami: Schools Helping Schools in Aceh
results.creator_credit: ABC Asia Pacific and Barry Mitchell
results.brief_description: On 26th December 2004, a massive earthquake in the Indian Ocean caused the tsunamis that devastated many nearby coastal areas, with no area more profoundly affected than the province of Aceh in Indonesia. Over 150,000 people were killed, many of them school students, their parents and teachers, and many schools were partly, or completely destroyed. Governments all over the world offered money and aid, but even small organisations can have a big impact. The International Baccalaureate Organisation set up its ‘schools to schools’ program especially to connect schools in tsunami-affected regions with schools in Australia and other countries. This documentary shows how schools in Indonesia have started to pick up the pieces, and how the IBO is helping to rebuild.

results.title: After the Montreal massacre
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Nicole Hubert and Gerry Rogers
results.brief_description: In 1989 Marc Lepine shot and killed 14 women students. As he opened fire he yelled “You’re all a bunch of feminists”. This program is a useful tool not only in analysing this femicide, but throws light on what has become an increasing trend of male violence against women. Sylvie Gagnon, a survivor of the massacre, and other Canadian women talk of their fears, the influence of the media and social conditions, the Women’s Movement and the need to be empowered. The pervasive thread underlying their narrative is that violence towards women is not a solitary act committed by a disturbed personality, but instilled into the cultural and social fabric of society as one of the most pervasive yet least recognised violations of Human Rights. The haunting images taken on the day of the massacre and in the days following, are terrifying and moving, challenging us to explore the urgent issues of misogyny, male violence and sexism.

results.title: After the miracle
results.brief_description: A broad view of life in Israel in 1966. Covers economic and social development and some problems; the settling of millions of immigrants, the continuous threat of invasion, the lack of natural resources. Discusses the active and varied religious and political life, and the advanced state of science and technology

results.title: After the harvest
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Victorian College of Agriculture and Horticulture and Robin Wischusen
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Growing awareness: Factors in plant production”.
Overviews the marketing of horticultural products in both domestic and international markets with basic marketing principles being applied to specialised products from the commercial garden. Topics discussed: understanding the market, buyer behaviour, packaging, storage, the impact of chemical use, pricing, competition, market research and an analysis of the technological developments which ensure a product is delivered in a marketable condition.

results.title: After the glaciers
results.brief_description: Shows how much of the northern hemisphere surged back to abundant life during the periods of ice age retreat. Follows the pattern of plant succession, from lichens to mosses, to a forest.

results.title: After the First
results.creator_credit: Teleketics, Karl Holtsnider and Nicholas Frangakis
results.brief_description: An open-ended film which explores a young boy’s emotions throughout his first hunting trip. Describes how the boy’s initial excitement, his mother’s concern and his father’s impatient pride all come together at the climactic moment of the killing. Designed to promote discussion on violence, fathers and sons, ecology, growing up and social conditioning. Designed to promote discussion on violence, fathers and sons, ecology, growing up and social conditioning.
